"I am not trying to be a historian and a dramatist; I'm a dramatist, a dramatic historian, or one who does a dramatic interpretation of history." - Oliver Stone 

JFK is a long, wavering, and intellectually superimposing picture. But it is also brilliant. It carves its drama based on actual events -- the assassination of the thirty-fifth president of the United States, John F. Kennedy. What is mesmerizing about JFK is its meticulous approach to adapting a real life historical phenomenon through known actors and its disinterring deductive arguments. JFK is skeptical, yes, but it also does not flinch in telling a story. It becomes so eager in exposing the clandestine assassination that the film becomes a conspiracy itself. Oliver Stone tells a convincing tale and he covers every angle. By the end of it all, you'll be locked in Stone's conscience. It tells you what the director think happened but that does not necessarily make it true or defined. It reveals only the possible. After such an unexpected event, there needed to be an angle. Something to point us in a direction, whether it is valid or not.

JFK does not perhaps work as a reliable history lesson, because history class inhibits facts and is hesitant on interpretation. Stone acts as a dramatic historian -- it allows him to incorporate his opinions in the factual evidence. What dirt can this director dig up? His story revolves around the real life story of Jim Garrison (Kevin Costner), a New Orleans District Attorney who applies witnesses, evidence, and pure conjecture in discovering who, in fact, killed Kennedy. Stone, though far from my favourite directors, plays his cards right here. Stone often got wrapped up in character-centred stories (Natural Born Killers and Alexander) that it snared his ability to tell a general story around a pursuable onlooker. JFK is a kinetic causal pyramid not a forgettable cat and mouse game. Events build up to a pinnacle pay off. Okay, so Stone eventually relinquishes to court room drama, but he will save himself (I promise, I will elaborate later on).

JFK has a stellar opening. It presents itself onscreen as an intellectual tool. It's in documentary style and the commencing credits allude to the cocking of the gun that shot Kennedy. Through documentary footage alone, Stone grabs our attention. Then JFK snowballs into a back and forth narrative of Garrison's journey in revealing the culprits of the assassination and then effortlessly cutting to the pre-assassination shenanigans between the suspects: Lee Harvey Oswald (Gary Oldman), Guy Bannister (Edward Asner), and Clay Shaw (Tommy Lee Jones). Well, the last two are actually witnesses who interacted with Lee Harvey Oswald. They may just be the gateway to unraveling something much more intricate and elaborate than anyone once thought. That's what drives JFK. Its mystery floods the screen. The characters's motives are so vague that we can't help but allow Stone to gradually reveal them to us. 

Stone's film is compacted with credibility because it interprets a real life story that questioned the assassination. It's not just Stone's thoughts, it's his dramatic application on another's thoughts. In the end, they ultimately have to be perceived as the directors. His build is extravagant. His pace is slick. There are numerous things happening at once but Stone always provides a voice over to guide us through the sequences. We watch each event and put the pieces together ourselves. By the end of JFK, we have our own little conspiracy theory.

There is even a laconic scene involving Donald Sutherland, playing a retired agent named X. As cliché as the pseudonym comes across, the rendezvous between X and Jim untwines another thread of the plot. As X claims, he can provide Jim with the background, all Jim needs to do is establish the foreground. It is subtext: to all the audience, it is up to you to put it all together. Stone will provide us with the skeptical theories and our interpretations will undoubtedly rectify. Don't be surprised. Your solutions may precisely compare to the directors.

Stone also handles the family side to Garrison's life with care. We are compelled to watch Jim interact with his concerned wife (played by Sissy Spacek) and his few children because Stone ascertains an important dilemma. Jim is distant from his family because he wants to create a just country for his children. Not a place where we will always bury our head in the sand. His wife insists he is not loving anymore; his impassive approach to them is crushing. Especially in these times. Stone envisions this scenario properly: to certain degrees, both Jim and his wife are both right.

JFK slightly underplays itself in the third act. Garrison endures a trial against Clay Shaw, claiming he was an accomplice in the assassination. Inevitably, JFK had to wallow in courtroom drama, for this is what happened in Garrison's tumultuous yet esteemed career in 1969. Stone is toying with historical inquiry not historical fact. But that climactic turn is just so unwelcoming. JFK starts to conclude its ideas on a too literal note. It feels as if Jim Garrison is talking at the camera -- with a sombre retrospective, he feeds us his ideas. For a director, it is too obvious. Too plain. But in all fairness, Stone rescues this sequence through some suave editing. After a daunting ten minute speech by Costner, the recollecting events combine into a flawless answer. Stone has his interpretation delivered on a silver platter.

Stone masters JFK because he fulfills the story with pungent ideas and palpitating drama. Was the government in fact involved in killing their own leader? Okay, that's a stretch, Stone. Or is it? JFK is that good with its persuasiveness. It covers every angle up until no other reasoning seems applicable or available. Just Stone's. JFK, as a result, is more of a historical theory than a cinematic afterthought. It handles this daunting event with emotion, dilemmas, mystery, and a myriad of questions. Was there something more to Kennedy's killing that didn't end with Oswald? One thing's for sure, there is something more to Stone. He truly is a virtuoso in historical drama.

"JFK" is all exposition, and even if the movie holds our attention it has no dramatic arc. In filmmaking technique, Stone incorporates color with black and white, archival footage, photographs, and historical reenactments for the purpose of propaganda. The large ensemble cast includes Joe Pesci, Gary Oldman as Lee Harvey Oswald, Donald Sutherland, Kevin Bacon, Jack Lemmon, Walther Matthau, John Candy, Laurie Metcalf, Michael Rooker, Vincent D'Onofrio. Oliver Stone has created his masterpiece, in my eyes, with 1991's "JFK," a film about John F. Kennedy's assassination and one man's obsession of finding out the "truth" about who shot the president. Historians have ripped the film apart for its inaccuracies and flaws in logic to the point where the film can't be seen as what really happened on that infamous day in November 1963, but I find it being wrong in the facts department to be quite arbitrary: it's still an interesting story with an urgent narrative and the kind of film details -- film editing, cinematography -- that are frequently studied in film classes. It's a movie based on opinion, and so what if the opinion has proved to be faulty; "JFK" is a testament to free speech -- isn't it great to have that at our disposal?! -- and the emotions that overpower our logic.


While the title suggest that Kennedy plays an active role himself, he is only seen in brief, grainy home video footage that plays over in the film's most powerful scenes. Instead, the film follows Jim Garrison, a New Orleans district attorney (played by Kevin Costner) that believes without a shadow of a doubt that Lee Harvey Oswald didn't act alone (or, perhaps, wasn't even responsible for the assassination) on November 22, 1963 and that we were deceived by the Warren Report that claims that Oswald was the lone gunman. Claiming a conspiracy on the government's part is a very risky thing, but to Garrison everything doesn't seem right: witnesses claiming they saw something over a grassy knoll, Oswald is conveniently murdered before a trial could be put together, and the bullet that killed Kennedy had a near to impossible route to make the police reports factual.


A three hour film about a man obsessing over Kennedy's assassination? How could this be thrilling entertainment? "JFK" is not a spectator's film -- it insists you invest at least some emotion while Garrison fetches clues to solve a grand-scale murder mystery that already has an answer -- and is three hours long with "clues" that, at the end of the day, could just as well be dead ends. We aren't any closer into figuring out who killed John F. Kennedy than we were before watching "JFK," but isn't the thrill of watching one alternate scenario play out enough? For me, it was.

To study this film is to analyze an expertly crafted epic drama from a director that constantly forces his audience to think outside of what we are taught -- his 1986 war film "Platoon" has a very different view of the Vietnam War: The United States weren't always the "good guys." From a technical standpoint, this is a film teacher's dream: the film shifts from the present (in this context, 1966) to the infamous day (November 22, 1963) at lightning fact speed, with a film technique that allows a viewer to know if they are watching something from the past or present -- the past footage of "witnesses" is played in grainy black and white. This isn't an acting piece -- several of the high profile actors waved their usual fees to work for scale, as they considered the project too important to pass up -- but the performances are solid; Tommy Lee Jones as Clay Shaw, a shady businessman that Garrison suspects to be a big part in the conspiracy is a standout. It should be noted that there is no attempt on Kevin Costner's part to play Jim Garrison as a complicated character with a level of acting prowess that Costner has never shown; Costner plays Garrison as a man with simple emotions, gaining respect as a capable leading man here. It's a thankless job, but Costner wisely knows that this isn't the time to try and put on an overblown acting performance in hopes of an Academy Award nomination. It's a movie that is larger than life, and the actors have the easiest job of the movie (a statement you aren't likely to hear in many of my reviews) -- the blunt of the responsibility is placed on director and co-writer Oliver Stone's shoulders and everybody must share in his passion to bringing this tale to the screen.

When it's all said and done, do I believe in Jim Garrison's theories? It's an opinion, but I don't. I find it quite "convenient" that Lee Harvey Oswald was able to successfully achieve what he did on November 22, 1963 all by himself, but I doubt the government killed Kennedy. Maybe Oswald had an accomplice with him that somehow got away? Maybe Oswald was a lucky shot? Maybe. Regardless of my feelings on the Kennedy assassination, I find "JFK" something I can get lost into easily. It's somewhat cheesy and tactless to call a movie with such a plot line as entertaining, but such is by far my opinion of the film.

Ever since that fateful day in Dealy Plaza, there has been much ado about the events surrounding the assassination of John F. Kennedy. The Warren Commission, which was put together after the events, concluded that Oswald acted alone in his efforts to kill Kennedy. In spite of this, many people in this country have different feelings as to what went down in Dallas.

This film is largely a chronicle of one particular conspiracy theory that surrounds the death of President Kennedy, as well as the story about the one D.A. to bring a charge against someone for the death of JFK. The D.A., of course, is Jim Garrison, played by Kevin Costner. I'm not a huge fan of Costner as an actor, mainly because he's either really good or really bad in his roles. For every Field of Dreams and Dances With Wolves, there's a Waterworld or Wyatt Earp to destroy your image of him as an top-flight actor.

Luckily, JFK is one of his better roles. He adopts a fairly good Yat accent for his role as a New Orleanian, and we really feel for the guy as he's on his almost obsessive crusade to find truth.

As stated previously, this film is about Garrison's attempt to make light of a dark and complicated subject. Just as broken up as the rest of America immediately after the assassination of the President, years later, he's tipped off to reopen a previously closed investigation of pilot David Ferrie (Pesci), an associate of Lee Harvey Oswald (Oldman) while Oswald was in New Orleans. During this time, Garrison flies to Washington DC with Sen. Russel Long (Matthau), who himself expresses doubts as to the validity and accuracy of the Warren Commission findings, which actually leads Garrison to read the entirety of the report himself. After reading the Warren Commission report and finding inaccuracies. His office then interviews various people connected with Ferrie, which eventually leads him to Clay "Bertrand" (Jones). 

On another trip to DC, Garrison meets with X (Sutherland), a mysterious Air Force colonel who explains his belief that there is a grand conspiracy at various levels of government, crime (Mafia), and the overall military-industrial complex. This helps to further resolve Garrison to continue to his investigation, which leads to various consequences, including threats to his life and trouble at home with his wife (Spacek). 

Eventually, Garrison gathers enough evidence to charge Clay Shaw for the murder of John F. Kennedy, as a part of a much larger conspiracy. During the trial, he goes to express outrage at the Warren Commission's belief in a single-bullet theory (proposed by current Republican US Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, then a lawyer for the Justice Department). In his closing remarks, Garrison concludes that there is evidence that the assassination of JFK was a coup d'tat, involving the highest levels of government.

One certainly cannot deny Oliver Stone's guts for making a movie surrounding this chain of events. He took a lot of heat, and continues to take a lot of heat, for making a movie about Jim Garrison's investigation into this particular conspiracy theory. I've heard people refer to this movie as one of the most haphazard, dangerous movie of all time, because the idea that someone would glorify Garrison for digging deep into this event following a conspiracy, no matter how false it may be, could be a traitorous act. I don't see it that way. At its time of release, there was actually talk of censoring parts of the film. While it's regrettable that due to this movie, many people reference this movie as being fact, I don't see anything wrong with giving Jim Garrison his side of the story.

With that having been said, there are aspects of this movie I didn't like. I found it extremely confusing to follow, in part due to the film-making. It seemed that this film was going 100 miles per hour, trying to jam every bit of information in that it possibly could. While there was certainly a lot surrounding this story, I thought it could have been better condensed and more understandable. 

The acting in this film was first rate. Costner was fantastic as the in-over-his-head Jim Garrison. Tommy Lee Jones was also very good as Clay Shaw, the defendent in the JFK trial. Also of note is Joe Pesci's turn as David Ferrie, the man who eventually led Garrison to Bertrand/Shaw, and Donald Sutherland steals the screen in his very short segment as X.

This film has had a lasting cultural impact. While the merits of truth may not be there, this film did (and still does) help in getting society to ask questions of their government again. Government isn't always trustworthy, and we as a people need to do our part to keep it in check. I recommend this movie for anyone that enjoys a good conspiracy theory thriller, anyone willing to see a different side to the JFK story, or someone who just likes groundbreaking films.

In case the film's title doesn't give you a big enough hint, JFK follows New Orleans District Attorney Jim Garrison and his investigation into what he thinks was one of the biggest cover-ups in American history: the assassination of President John F. Kennedy...and who (or better yet, how many) killed him.  Staring an ensemble like no other, which includes Kevin Costner, Tommy Lee Jones, Kevin Bacon, Sissy Spacek, Jack Lemmon, Joe Pesci, Donald Sutherland, etc. and they all are in top form in this mesmerizing drama.  

Apart from the great performances, the thing that really struck me was the editing and the cinematography.  Re-creating November 22. 1963 this perfectly must have been one of the most painstakingly tedious projects a director could undertake, but Stone does it with such finesse that you may start to think you are watching the History channel, and not a re-created set.

Conspiracy theories themselves set forth their own kind of narrative. Whether they are accurate or not  doesn't matter. Its the chance that something so cunning and against the majority actually happened, entrances every part of us.  Its this idea that we've been bamboozled is what is so enticing. "How could they have possibly done that? Is this true?" Oliver Stone knows this and he puts it to use on one of the greatest and most jarring assassination in American history: JFK's assassination in Dallas. Stone creates a kinetic film that tries to reconstruct this conspiracy through the eyes of Jim Garrison, the district attorney of New Orleans who himself did try and bring this conspiracy to court. With the intercuts of archival footage and film footage, along with recreations, Stone drops into Dallas and asks to "look closer" and find our own truth. In this three hour opus, we are entrenched with Kevin Costner's Garrison, who is just like us, someone who is trying to find truth amongst what doesn't make sense, as well as trying to not let it consume him. With each minute we spend with Garrison, we start to believe his theory more and more, and soon as it engulfs him, its engulfs us as we need to know the truth. Soon, we're going mad and we start to see each kernel of truth as it begins to unfold in front of us and it all leads to a dramatic court room scene that has Costner giving one of the most stirring monologues I've heard on film. And then we realize that the film isn't about proving a theory right. Instead its about the right as an american citizen to question and dig at the burning questions that haunt our minds and souls. Of course there must be an advisory for this film: do not take every photo, every shred of evidence for fact. Much of the films points are based on some evidence, but don't let this be the brunt of your evidential weight. Instead realize that some of these things did happen, but they may be embellished to a degree inorder to create a fluid and moving story.
